bioghist.p: Israel Stiefel (1898-1966) was born in Odessa and emigrated to the United States in the early 1920s. Stiefel served in the Pennsylvania Senate from 1936-1964, representing the 5th Senatorial District in Philadelphia, and becoming Chairman of the Democratic Senate Caucus. He was active in introducing legislation promoting historic preservation, conservation, and aid to medical education, among his other causes. Stiefel also taught at the University of Pennsylvania and at Temple University.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Israel Stiefel. Papers from Stiefel's student days include papers written for undergraduate and graduate courses, course notes, examinations, and diplomas. Family papers include Stiefel's immigration and naturalization papers, and those of his of his mother Ethel and his sister Soshana. There are also a small number of telegrams and letters from family members. Papers related to Stiefel's senatorial career include correspondence with constituents and other government employees and politicians; acts and amendments; scrapbooks and clippings on elections and legislation; addresses; and political memorabilia and photographs. The collection also includes papers related to his adjunct professorship at Temple; legal digests and notes for lectures; scrapbooks and clippings related to his activities involving the Jewish community and his membership in B'nai Brith; publications and addresses; and photographs and memorabilia from his visits to Israel. A number of letters and printed documents in the collection are in Hebrew and a few are in Russian.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
